interaction_summary:
=== Purchase Information ===
Product Title: A Night to Remember (The Criterion Collection) [Blu-ray]
Review Date: 2021/06/11
Store: Kenneth More  (Actor),     Honor Blackman  (Actor),     Roy Ward Baker  (Director)    &                   0                  more   Rated:    Unrated    Format: Blu-ray
Categories: Movies & TV, Blu-ray, Movies
Product Description: ['On April 14, 1912, just before midnight, the unsinkable Titanic struck an iceberg. In less than three hours, it had plunged to the bottom of the sea, taking with it more than 1,500 of its 2,200 passengers. In his unforgettable rendering of Walter Lord’s book of the same name,', 'A Night to Remember', ', the acclaimed British director Roy Ward Baker (', 'Don’t Bother to Knock', ') depicts with sensitivity, awe, and a fine sense of tragedy the ship’s final hours. Featuring remarkably restrained performances,', 'A Night to Remember', 'is cinema’s subtlest, finest dramatization of this monumental twentieth-century catastrophe.']
Average Rating: 4.7
Product Details: {'Genre': 'Drama, Documentary/Biography', 'Format': 'Blu-ray', 'Contributor': 'Roy Ward Baker, Kenneth More, David McCallum, Tucker McGuire, Honor Blackman, Michael Goodliffe', 'Language': 'English', 'Runtime': '2 hours and 3 minutes', 'Is Discontinued By Manufacturer': 'No', 'MPAA rating': 'Unrated (Not Rated)', 'Product Dimensions': '0.7 x 7.5 x 5.4 inches; 3.2 Ounces', 'Item model number': 'CRRN2133BR', 'Director': 'Roy Ward Baker', 'Media Format': 'Blu-ray', 'Run time': '2 hours and 3 minutes', 'Release date': 'March 27, 2012', 'Actors': 'Kenneth More, Honor Blackman, Michael Goodliffe, David McCallum, Tucker McGuire', 'Subtitles': 'English', 'Studio': 'Criterion Collection', 'Country of Origin': 'USA', 'Number of discs': '1'}
Review Text: Still the beat film dramatization of the sinking of the RMS Titanic. Yes it doesn’t have the technical details of the final moment right (ship breaking up not confirmed until the reck was found well after this movie was made), but it’s a far better film than Titanic.
Review Title: Best Titanic Dramatization
Rating: 5.0
--------------------------------------------------

Yojimbo (The Criterion Collection) [Blu-ray]
Toshir Mifune  (Actor),     Eijir Tno  (Actor),     Akira Kurosawa  (Director, Writer)    &                   0                  more   Rated:    NR    Format: Blu-ray
Movies & TV, Blu-ray, Movies
["Thanks to perhaps the most indelible character in Akira Kurosawa's oeuvre, Yojimbo surpassed even Seven Samurai in popularity when it was released. The masterless samurai Sanjuro, who slyly manipulates two warring clans to his advantage."]

My favorite Kurosawa film. Great story and acting, highly recommend.
Kurosawa at his best

profile:
**User Profile Summary:**

**Content Preferences:**
- Strong preference for classic cinema, with a specific interest in Japanese film and works by renowned director Akira Kurosawa, showcasing a taste for high-quality storytelling and character development.
- Recent engagement with historical dramas indicates an appreciation for films that combine intense narratives with significant real-world events, maintaining a balance between artistic portrayal and factual basis.

**Format and Quality:**
- Prefers high-quality formats, specifically Blu-ray, indicating an appreciation for superior audiovisual experiences.
- Enjoys special editions that may include enhanced features, packaging, or subtitles, reflecting a desire for comprehensive viewing experiences.

**Rating Behavior:**
- Consistently rates content highly (often 5-star ratings), demonstrating a discerning taste and satisfaction with well-crafted films. The user recently praised a film for its superior dramatization and strong performances, aligning with their typical engagement with critically acclaimed works.

**Community Engagement:**
- Actively recommends films to peers, emphasizing the value of community feedback and the sharing of quality content. 

Overall, this user showcases a refined preference for classic, critically acclaimed cinema, particularly from Japanese filmmakers, while also embracing well-executed historical narratives in high-quality formats. Their tastes reflect a continued pursuit of captivating storytelling and cinematic excellence.
